repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Second National Fadama
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second National Fadama
            Development Project for Nigeria were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: the Fadama program is
            illustrative of the risks that are attendant in neglecting
            social analysis in technical work streams. The
            project's first phase contributed to conflict between
            natural resource users groups by financing activities that
            expanded livelihood benefits to one user group at the
            expense of others. The sustainability of community-based
            initiatives depends crucially on an enabling institutional
            environment, which requires government commitment, and on
            accountability of leaders to their community to avoid
            'supply-driven demand-driven' development.
            Programs designed to change behavior need to be grounded in
            a deep understanding of context; they need to be willing to
            engage in a study of what motivates people. Programs
            implemented at scale should include a sensitive design that
            takes into account the different cultural, linguistic and
            ethnic characteristics of the targeted population. Programs
            designed to change behavior also require observational and
            qualitative indicators that in turn, require capacity
            building and implementation support to tweak project
            assumptions and project adjust design in real time.

docna.cdata!: Nigeria - Second National Fadama Development Project

Nigeria - Second National Fadama

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Culture of feedback key to
            boosting community participation and building rural livelihoods

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about the
            culture of feedback, key to boosting community participation
            and building rural livelihoods in Nigeria. Increased focus
            on generating community feedback in the Nigeria Fadama
            project, funded by the World Bank, is helping to improve
            rural livelihoods by deepening the quality and quantity of
            communication between development practitioners,
            governments, and community members. The farmers have
            struggled in the face of grinding poverty and livelihoods
            have been undercut by low agricultural yields. The project
            has developed a vibrant network of inclusive community
            networks. It has also launched a promising mobile phone and
            SMS-based system that will allow beneficiaries to provide
            feedback on a variety of indicators from the performance of
            project staff to suggestions on how to improve the timing of
            funds disbursement. It is currently operating in all the 36
            states of Nigeria including the Federal Capital Territory.
            The World Bank has also provided technical assistance,
            drawing upon its experience with community driven
            development approaches in other countries. Fadama project
            has built strong networks of community associations and user
            groups and piloting of an SMS network should be seen as a
            starting point for a system of feedback mechanisms that can
            provide both more quantitative and more qualitative
            information on project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Building macroeconomic stability
            and delivering services for the poor

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            building macroeconomic stability and delivering services for
            the poor in Nigeria. Despite Nigeria’s strong economic track
            record, poverty is significant, and reducing it would
            require strong non-oil growth and a focus on human
            development. National Urban Water Sector Reform Project
            addressed the fundamental causes of the problem, and ensured
            improved governance at all levels. As a result, projects in
            various sectors had seen positive results in education,
            health, and the delivery of clean water in the country.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Second National Fadama
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about Second
            National Fadama Development Project (Fadama II) in Nigeria.
            Fadama is a name for irrigable land found along
            Nigeria's major river systems. The land is fertile and
            water is easily accessible, but the Fadamas have also been
            the scene of conflict among farmers, fishermen, and
            pastoralists who are vying for land, water, and grazing
            resources. The Fadama II project introduced, Local
            Development Plans (LDP) which brought resource user groups
            together in identifying the development priorities of their
            respective communities and translating these priorities into
            investment. Through community empowerment, participatory
            development planning and support for demand-driven
            productive investments in farm and nonfarm activities,
            Nigeria has boosted incomes for over 3 million farm families
            by 63 percent.

docna.cdata!: Nigeria - Second National Fadama Development Project

Nigeria - Second National Fadama

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Second National Fadama
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second National Fadama
            Development Project for Nigeria were as follows: outcomes
            were highly satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, Bank performance was highly satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also highly satisfactory. Lessons
            learned include: empowering community organizations with
            resources and enhancing their capacity to manage these
            directly through community driven development (CDD) approach
            enhances efficiency and sustainability of targeted
            poverty-reduction projects. Until the capacity of the poor
            farmers has been sufficiently developed to improve their
            limitations and creditworthiness for traditional
            microfinance institutions, it is inevitable that they should
            be assisted with grants in order to participate in
            Fadama-type livelihood activities. Socially-inclusive
            approach to local development planning (LDP) can be an
            effective tool for avoiding and managing conflicts arising
            from competition to access scarce land and water resources
            for Fadama enterprise. It is the central paradigm shift
            around which the entire Fadama system revolves. Keep an eye
            on sustainability of project supported interventions.
            Selection and management of subprojects by communities and
            their cost sharing in the matching grant facilitate
            sustainability. In order to lay a sound basis for
            sustainability, operations and maintenance of assets should
            be undertaken by communities and local governments, through
            operations and maintenance (O&M) plans to be funded
            partly in cash or in-kind by the community organizations.
